author: By Muyi Xiao, Haley Willis, Christoph Koettl, Natalie Reneau and Drew Jordan
title: China Is Using Uighur Labor to Produce Face Masks
description: A Times video investigation identified Chinese companies using a contentious labor program for Uighurs to satisfy demand for P.P.E., some of which ended up in the United States and other countries.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic continues to drive demand for personal protective equipment, Chinese companies are rushing to manufacture the gear for domestic and global consumption. A New York Times visual investigation has found that some of those companies are using Uighur labor through a contentious government-sponsored program that experts say often puts people to work against their will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Heska Wanbli Weiden
title: This 19th-Century Law Helps Shape Criminal Justice in Indian Country
description: And that’s a problem — especially for Native American women, and especially in rape cases.
content: There was something of a scramble, after the Supreme Court ruled in McGirt v. Oklahoma that much of Eastern Oklahoma was now officially Indian Country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman, Kate Kelly and Jennifer Medina
title: How Buying Beans Became a Political Statement
description: The boycott and counter-boycott of Goya comes as the major political parties seek to energize Hispanic support ahead of the 2020 election.
content: For years, the Goya brand was synonymous with the Latino-American dream. The sheer number of products that lined the grocery store aisles — from refried pinto beans to sazón con azafran seasoning — spoke to the growing number of Hispanic immigrants who bought them. Goya, the nation’s largest Hispanic food company, has sponsored Dominican art shows, mariachi contests and soccer programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos, Rick Rojas and Mike Baker
title: From Antifa to Mothers in Helmets, Diverse Elements Fuel Portland Protests
description: Protesters have been in the streets for more than 50 consecutive days. Federal agents deployed to Portland have hardened their resolve to stay there.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Angela Foster started showing up in the early days of the protests in Portland as one of the novice activists standing off to the side with no gear to protect herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Luther Price, Experimental Artist and Filmmaker, Dies at 58
description: He explored family, sexuality and death, using found footage, emulsion scraps and dust bunnies as his medium. And he kept his real name a secret.
content: Luther Price, a multimedia artist and prolific experimental filmmaker known for his haunting, often transgressive work — as well as for never revealing his real name — died on June 13 at his home in Revere, Mass. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make a meal with what you have on hand, whether it’s chicken and rice soup, or a chickpea salad with herbs and scallions.
content: Good morning. Family meal is what restaurant people call the dinner served to the staff before service, which is the term they use to describe when the restaurant is open to customers. Family meals are generally made by a line cook, someone who works a particular station in the kitchen — the grill, say, or the stove. A line cook is not the restaurant’s chef, but answers to one or to the chef’s lieutenant, who is known as a sous chef. This is all in keeping with the system by which the French first organized the professional kitchen: a brigade de cuisine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz and Marie Fazio
title: Roger Stone Denies Using Racial Slur on Radio Show
description: Though the audio suggests otherwise, Mr. Stone said he did not use a slur in referring to his interviewer, who is Black. He also contended that the word was not offensive.
content: Roger Stone, the political operative who was spared a prison sentence this month by his friend President Trump, denied on Sunday that he had uttered a racial slur on a radio show the night before, calling the accusation a “smear” while also contending the word was not offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Nakotah LaRance, Acclaimed Native American Hoop Dancer, Dies at 30
description: A nine-time winner at the World Championship of Hoop Dance, he also performed with Cirque du Soleil.
content: Nakotah LaRance, a nationally acclaimed Hopi-Tewa hoop dancer who performed with Cirque du Soleil, died on July 12 near the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo in New Mexico. He was 30.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After #OscarsSoWhite, Disability Waits for Its Moment
description: Actors with disabilities are rarely tapped to play disabled characters. Ali Stroker, Marlee Matlin and others share their views on representation in the entertainment industry.
content: This article is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for disabled people. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Special Interests Mobilize to Get Piece of Next Virus Relief Package
description: Congress is about to start negotiating in earnest over another round of stimulus, and a frenzy of lobbying is already underway.
content: WASHINGTON — Airlines, hotels and restaurants. Military contractors and banks. Even Broadway actors. These are just a few of the special interests already maneuvering to get a piece of the next coronavirus relief package about to be taken up by Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Partyers Clash With German Police
description: Tensions are running high in the country amid a national debate on racial profiling in police ranks.
content: BERLIN — Violence erupted overnight in Frankfurt between police officers and youths who have been partying in a central city square on weekends, with bars and clubs shuttered to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Testing Backlogs May Cloud the True Spread of the Coronavirus
description: Public health experts say delays in testing continue to hinder attempts to track and contain the spread of disease.
content: As demand for coronavirus testing surges around the nation, laboratories that process samples are again experiencing backlogs that have left anxious patients and their doctors waiting days — sometimes a week or more — for results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Top State Dept. Officials Enabled Misconduct by Pompeo, Whistle-Blower Said
description: A newly public copy of the whistle-blower’s complaint says that top officials who were protecting the secretary of state blocked the whistle-blower from addressing the issue internally.
content: WASHINGTON — A State Department employee who reported witnessing misconduct by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo as well as hearing “numerous firsthand accounts” of such behavior was blocked from further addressing the issue by top department officials who were protecting Mr. Pompeo, according to a newly public copy of the employee’s whistle-blower complaint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson and Lynsey Addario
title: Vulnerable Border Community Battles Virus on ‘A Straight Up Trajectory’
description: In the Rio Grande Valley, poverty and chronic illness are aggravating the coronavirus outbreak. Ambulances stack up outside emergency rooms, where patients wait for beds.
content: EDINBURG, Texas — On a sweltering day last week near the southern tip of Texas, where high rates of poverty and chronic illness have heightened the ferocity of the coronavirus, Dr. Renzo Arauco Brown made his rounds, checking on patients who were facing severe complications from the virus and barely hanging on to life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Renaming the Army Bases
description: Readers applaud such a change, though one disagrees with an editorial board choice. Also: The unfairness of mandatory sentencing.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Death of John Lewis Fuels Movement to Rename Edmund Pettus Bridge
description: The bridge became a flash point on March 7, 1965, as protesters, led by Mr. Lewis and other civil rights leaders, were stopped and beaten by state troopers as they marched to Alabama’s capital.
content: The death of Representative John Lewis on Friday has renewed interest in a campaign to rename the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., the site of a turning point in the fight for civil rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Eskenazi
title: They Came From Moose Jaw and Kapuskasing. They Were the New York Rangers.
description: The team’s move to Canada to train and finish the N.H.L. season recalls a time in the 1960s and ’70s when training up there was standard. And most of the team was Canadian.
content: The pandemic has forced the N.H.L. to finish its season at two hubs in Canada, Edmonton and Toronto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Mars Mission From United Arab Emirates Embarks on 7-Month Journey
description: Lifting off from Tanegashima Space Center in Japan, it is the first of three missions headed to the red planet this summer.
content: You’ll be hearing a lot about Mars in the weeks to come this summer. Three missions are launching toward the red planet, taking advantage of the way Earth and its neighbor get closer every 26 months or so, allowing a relatively short trip between the two worlds. If they launch successfully, the spacecrafts will arrive at Mars early next year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘One Day While I Was Shopping at Macy’s, I Lost Track of the Time’
description: Trying to get a straight answer, shoeless at Coney Island and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: The Met Opera Tries to Find Paying Customers in a Pandemic
description: On Saturday, Jonas Kaufmann was first in a series of 12 livestreamed recitals featuring Met stars. Tickets are $20.
content: After the coronavirus pandemic forced concert halls and opera houses to close this spring, online performances proliferated. The Metropolitan Opera began streaming nightly operas from its extensive video archive, and in April it presented an At-Home Gala, broadcast over smartphones from the homes of singers around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Why a ‘Do No Harm’ General Election Strategy Could Work for Joe Biden
description: Mr. Biden is running a risk-averse campaign in states like Wisconsin, where a broad coalition of supporters is emerging. Even Republicans are noticing.
content: ADAMS, Wis. — Nate Zimdars, a Democratic candidate for the Wisconsin State Assembly, arrived at the V.F.W. lodge here after marching in the local Independence Day parade, ready to meet voters at an annual outdoor chicken cookout called the “Chic Nic.” Although the event was hosted by the local Republican Party, Mr. Zimdars was far from nervous being behind enemy lines. He was eager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily M.D. Scott
title: Start Looking, and You’ll See Roads All Over the Bible
description: The pandemic has scattered us from our communal rituals. But that isn’t where our journey should end.
content: Once, my life was made of bread. I was the pastor of a “dinner church” where our worship took the form of a meal we cooked and ate together. Our church was filled not with pews, but with tables. Not with the heady smell of incense, but onions softening in olive oil and rosemary as the bread warmed in the oven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Kuwait Says 91-Year-Old Emir Had ‘Successful’ Surgery
description: No further explanation was given for the procedure, which could renew a power struggle in the Gulf nation’s ruling family.
content: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — The 91-year-old emir of Kuwait underwent a “successful” surgery on Sunday that required the crown prince of the oil-rich nation to be temporarily empowered to serve in his place, its state-run news agency reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: As Trump Ignores Virus Crisis, Republicans Start to Break Ranks
description: President Trump continues to press for a quick return to life as usual, but Republicans who fear a rampaging disease and angry voters are increasingly going their own way.
content: President Trump’s failure to contain the coronavirus outbreak and his refusal to promote clear public-health guidelines have left many senior Republicans despairing that he will ever play a constructive role in addressing the crisis, with some concluding they must work around Mr. Trump and ignore or even contradict his pronouncements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Makeup of a Beach
description: Alex Eaton-Salners bosses us around — must be Monday.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I regret that I don’t examine Monday puzzles too closely unless I have to postify them. Sure, we’re on the “easiest” day of the week in crossworld (making up for the challenges of Monday in, oh, every other aspect of our lives). That might mean fewer obscurities, a broader theme and much kinder crosses, but that doesn’t mean there aren’t a lot of intricate folds and facets, and it doesn’t mean that things are simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Keller
title: Why Intellectuals Support Dictators
description: Anne Applebaum’s “Twilight of Democracy” examines the role of thinkers and writers who back modern authoritarians.
content: TWILIGHT OF DEMOCRACYThe Seductive Lure of AuthoritarianismBy Anne Applebaum
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Where Is the Outrage?
description: Americans are getting sick and dying while Trump plays a political game.
content: It never ceases to amaze me how more people aren’t outraged, shocked and disgusted by Donald Trump’s cruelty and malfeasance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: 3 Dead After Glacier Tour Bus Rolls Over in Canadian Rockies
description: The vehicle, with 27 people on board, was specially designed to carry visitors onto one of North America’s largest glaciers, in Jasper National Park in Alberta.
content: OTTAWA — A popular tourist outing in the Rocky Mountains in Alberta turned into a scene of chaos after a glacier tour bus rolled on Saturday afternoon, killing three passengers and injuring 24 others on board, according to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: With Tourists Gone, St. Patrick’s Cathedral Pleads for Help
description: The Manhattan landmark is struggling to pay its bills while the pandemic keeps visitors and Midtown workers away.
content: St. Patrick’s Cathedral, one of the most famous churches in the United States, has long depended on tourists and office workers to fill its pews and its collection plates. But now that the coronavirus has left Midtown Manhattan largely deserted, it is facing a $4 million budget shortfall that may threaten its ability to pay its bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Trump’s Hot-Button Fed Pick Faces Senate Committee Vote This Week
description: Judy Shelton, a nominee for the powerful Federal Reserve Board who has unorthodox economic views, could advance to the full Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — Judy Shelton, an unorthodox economist who was an adviser to President Trump’s 2016 campaign, could move one step closer to a seat on the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Despite Masks’ Proven Value, Some U.S. Leaders Avoid Mandates
description: Health workers assigned to care for Brazil’s Indigenous people have exposed remote communities to the virus. Some Republican leaders are starting to distance themselves from President Trump’s handling of the pandemic.
content: As caseloads surge in many states, especially in the West and South, the debate over mask mandates continues, though evidence of their benefits has mounted substantially in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Civil Rights Icon Turned Conscience of Congress
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 19, 2020.
content: “This feels and looks so different. It is so much more massive and all inclusive. There will be no turning back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Petition Urges Trader Joe’s to Get Rid of ‘Racist Branding’
description: The supermarket chain said it was in the process of phasing out names, including Trader Ming’s and Trader José, that have appeared on its international food products.
content: Trader Joe’s is being urged to follow the example of other national food companies and rebrand products that critics say perpetuate racial stereotypes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Southern Europe Opens Its Doors to Tourists. Not Many Are Coming.
description: Most tourist beds are empty in Spain’s Canary Islands. Bookings are down in Italy despite government incentives. And ferries to the Greek islands are carrying less than half the load they once did.
content: ADEJE, Spain — Music blared from a beachfront cafe along the normally bustling southwestern coast of Tenerife, the largest of Spain’s Canary Islands. But several tables sat empty, a month after a Covid-19 lockdown had ended, and the doors to many resorts remained shut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boryana Dzhambazova and Patrick Kingsley
title: Showdown on Beach in Bulgaria Balloons Into Political Crisis
description: Bulgaria is gripped by its worst political turmoil since 2013, leading to calls for the government to resign.
content: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Leaked photographs of the prime minister. A police raid on the president’s office. A business tycoon’s takeover of a public beach. A looming no-confidence vote in the government. And the largest street protests in seven years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Gordon Bower, Inventive Memory Researcher, Is Dead at 87
description: In a long career at Stanford, he was known for elegant experiments that explored how we learn and how we remember.
content: Gordon H. Bower, a research psychologist who spent more than half a century studying how the brain learns and remembers, as well as a host of related subjects, and who was among the leaders in his field, died on June 17 at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus Surge, John Lewis, Fall Gardens: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Dorothy Parker’s Ashes Could Be Moved. Again.
description: The writer’s ashes may be disinterred when the N.A.A.C.P. moves its headquarters to Washington from Baltimore. But where should they go?
content: When the N.A.A.C.P. moves its headquarters from Baltimore to Washington in the coming years, there’s a small object from a backyard garden it doesn’t plan to take along: the ashes of the New York writer and critic Dorothy Parker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: To Buy This Basquiat, Swipe Right
description: The auction veteran Loic Gouzer is selling major works of art on his new app.
content: Testing the notion that blue-chip art can be sold with a swipe, the former Christie’s executive Loic Gouzer on Monday will use his new app as the auction block for a large drawing by Jean-Michel Basquiat that is estimated to sell for $8 million to $12 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman, Motoko Rich and Andrew Keh
title: The Tokyo Olympics Will Open a Year From Now. Maybe.
description: Japan has largely controlled the coronavirus. Large parts of the rest of the world, especially the United States, have not. A year before the rescheduled Games, that is still a major problem.
content: A year from now, the world will begin to gather in Japan to celebrate the opening of the Tokyo Olympics, which were originally supposed to begin this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni, Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
title: Brazil Health Workers May Have Spread Coronavirus to Indigenous People
description: Many people assigned to care for the Indigenous have been infected, exposing remote communities to the virus. Health workers say they have been plagued by insufficient testing and protective gear.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The telltale symptoms began in late May, about a week after government medical workers made a routine visit to the Kanamari Indigenous community in a remote part of the Amazon: Elderly members of the group were struggling to breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Twitter’s Mystery Hackers
description: Twitter’s hackers could have made chaos. Why didn’t they?
content: Good morning. A financial tip: When someone on the internet asks for Bitcoin and promises double your money back, it’s probably a lie. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: REI Faces Staff Backlash Over Response to Covid-19 Cases
description: The co-op has raced to respond to criticism from store workers about how it has handled coronavirus cases at reopened locations.
content: About 40 current and former employees of the outdoor equipment store REI in Grand Rapids, Mich., regularly communicate using the messaging app GroupMe. On July 6, they received a jarring note from a colleague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: During Coronavirus Lockdowns, Some Doctors Wondered: Where Are the Preemies?
description: Hospitals in several countries saw dips in premature births, which could be a starting point for future research.
content: This spring, as countries around the world told people to stay home to slow the spread of the coronavirus, doctors in neonatal intensive care units were noticing something strange: Premature births were falling, in some cases drastically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Last Dance’ and ‘United Shades of America’
description: Stream all 10 hours of Michael Jordan’s documentary series, and catch a new season of W. Kamau Bell’s CNN show.
content: THE LAST DANCE Stream on Netflix. After debuting on ESPN in May, all 10 hours of this Michael Jordan documentary are available to stream. The series, which was produced by ESPN Films, Netflix and Jordan himself, chronicles the athlete’s legacy and time with the Chicago Bulls, including the team’s storied 1998 season. As Wesley Morris wrote in his Critic’s Notebook for The New York Times, “The series is this ocean of archival game clips, dunk montages, smack talk, mea culpas, cigar smoking, backstabbing, frontstabbing, manfully restrained tears, endorsements of the triangle offense” and “interviews with anybody who even blinked at the N.B.A. from 1984 to 1998.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 19, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 19, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about artists in Newark amid the pandemic and protests misstated the name of a museum. It is the Newark Museum of Art, not the Newark Museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: The Book Review in Quarantine
description: Work that revolves around rows of bookshelves adjusts to a remote setting.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Uighur Labor, Indian Arrests, Mars Mission: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Trump Leans Into False Virus Claims in Combative Fox News Interview
description: The president grew agitated as he was fact-checked on polling, race relations and the coronavirus response by Chris Wallace of Fox News.
content: WASHINGTON — An agitated President Trump offered a string of combative and often dubious assertions in an interview aired Sunday, defending his handling of the coronavirus with misleading evidence, attacking his own health experts, disputing polls showing him trailing in his re-election race and defending people who display the Confederate flag as victims of “cancel culture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Trump Administration Balks at Funding for Testing and C.D.C. in Virus Relief Bill
description: Senate Republicans were infuriated after the Trump administration objected to provisions in a draft proposal, including allocating $25 billion to testing and contact tracing.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has balked at providing billions of dollars to fund coronavirus testing and shore up federal health agencies as the virus surges across the country, complicating efforts to reach agreement on the next round of pandemic aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Public Transit Officials Fear Virus Could Send Systems Into ‘Death Spiral’
description: Transit leaders are urging Congress to provide billions of dollars in aid, and warn of dire consequences if they decline.
content: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey Tumlin, who leads San Francisco’s $1.3 billion transit system, is in a hard spot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Man Who Cracked the Lottery
description: This a story about mortality — about our greed, hubris and, ultimately, humility.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: Which Country Will Triumph in the Post-Pandemic World?
description: Hint: It’s not the United States or China.
content: Imagine a country, a major Western economic power, where the coronavirus arrived late but the government, instead of denying and delaying, acted early. It was ready with tests and contact tracing to “flatten the curve” swiftly and limited its death rate to orders of magnitude lower than that of any other major Western industrial nation. Containing the virus allowed for a brief and targeted lockdown, which helped limit unemployment to only 6 percent. Amid a shower of international praise, the country’s boringly predictable leader experienced a huge spike in popular approval, to 70 percent from 40 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: More Resignations, but No Sign Yet of a Change in Gaming Culture
description: Since dozens of women spoke up about harassment in gaming last month, prominent industry figures have resigned. But has anything really changed?
content: First, a popular esports tournament was canceled. Next, top gaming studio executives stepped down. Then, a prominent talent management agency for video game streamers laid off its employees and closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher R. Weingarten
title: Krip-Hop Nation Showcases Rappers With Disabilities. Meet 5 of Our Favorites.
description: Hear tracks by hip-hop musicians addressing otherizing media depictions, challenges and perseverance.
content: This playlist is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for disabled people. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees and Mets Glad to Finally Face Someone Other Than Themselves
description: Exhibition games replaced practices and intrasquad scrimmages as the New York teams prepared for the start of their regular-season schedule later this week.
content: Major League Baseball during a pandemic looks like this: A masked hitter smashing a home run, a bottle of hand sanitizer hanging from an umpire’s waistband, cardboard cutouts of fans positioned in the seats behind home plate, artificial cheering used after plays that benefited the home team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Fahim Abed
title: India Offers Escape to Afghan Hindus and Sikhs Facing Attacks
description: Members of the dwindling minority communities, gutted by recent deadly violence, welcomed an emergency exit but expressed worry that what would await them in India is poverty.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Indian government said it will expedite visas and the possibility of long-term residency for Afghanistan’s tiny Hindu and Sikh minorities, shrunken by decades of persecution and decimated by attacks in recent years amid the Afghan war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Kai Schultz
title: India Rounds Up Critics Under Shadow of Virus Crisis, Activists Say
description: The Indian authorities arrested dozens of people during a nationwide lockdown. Human rights groups say many of the detentions are based on scant evidence.
content: NEW DELHI — After spending several anxious days in prison, Natasha Narwal, a student activist accused of rioting by the New Delhi police, thought her ordeal was nearing an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: ‘Demagogue’ Remembers a Vintage American Bully
description: Larry Tye talks about his new biography of Joseph McCarthy, the senator whose name is synonymous with reckless accusation and fear-mongering.
content: “It’s not often that a man’s name becomes an ism,” Larry Tye writes in his new biography of Joseph McCarthy, the senator from Wisconsin whose crusade against Communism ensured that his name would endure as “a synonym for reckless accusation, guilt by association, fear-mongering and political double-dealing.” Tye writes in his preface that while the book focuses on McCarthy’s life, it’s also about a particularly American strain of demagogy that has existed from the country’s earliest days to Huey Long to George Wallace to the “astonishing ascension of President Donald J. Trump.” Below, Tye discusses McCarthy’s fanaticism, his enablers, his military experience and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Amid a Deadly Virus and Crippled Economy, One Form of Aid Has Proved Reliable: Food Stamps
description: In the first three months of the coronavirus pandemic, more than six million people joined a program the Trump administration tried to cut.
content: WASHINGTON — More than six million people enrolled in food stamps in the first three months of the coronavirus pandemic, an unprecedented expansion that is likely to continue as more jobless people deplete their savings and billions in unemployment aid expires this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chai Dingari and Asaf Kastner
title: Clearly, the Virus Isn’t the Only Problem
description: There’s a reason the U.S. is failing at containing Covid-19.
content: There’s a reason the U.S. is failing at containing Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muyi Xiao, Haley Willis, Christoph Koettl, Natalie Reneau and Drew Jordan
title: Wearing a Mask? It May Come From China’s Controversial Labor Program
description: Our visual investigation reveals that several Chinese companies are using Uighur labor from a contentious government program to produce P.P.E. during the pandemic. We track some of that equipment to the U.S. and around the world.
content: Our visual investigation reveals that several Chinese companies are using Uighur labor from a contentious government program to produce P.P.E. during the pandemic. We track some of that equipment to the U.S. and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times
